intro: Erythrostemon laxus, commonly known as the looseleaf mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton, hibiscus, and okra, and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in desert scrub and chaparral habitats. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a fuzzy texture, while its stems are hairy and somewhat succulent. Erythrostemon laxus is adapted to arid environments and is drought-tolerant, making it a hardy plant in xeriscaped gardens.
